title: If I marry an inmate in a California prison will I be held responsible for his restitution/debt or get sued?
question: The restitution and debt was incurred before we marry. I read that there's a possibility if I marry him I could get sued to pay his restitution or my taxes taken if he owes.
answers:
Well, if you have community property, a creditor might be able to attach joint property - such as a joint bank account, a jointly titled house or a joint tax return.

If you divorce the court will see debts from before the marriage as his separate debt.

A prenuptial agreement will protect you to some extent but should be recorded to give notice. A prenuptial agreement will not protect you when joint property is seized.

See the terms of FC 910 and onward: 910. (a) Except as otherwise expressly provided by statute, the
community estate is liable for a debt incurred by either spouse before or during marriage, regardless of which spouse has the management and control of the property and regardless of whether one or both spouses are parties to the debt or to a judgment for the debt.
Not if you have a prenup . Think, hard, before you do this.
